explanation: To determine whether UT_ClearDefaultReturnValue violates the “no recursion” rule you must examine any functions it calls and any functions those call (i.e., all reachable callees) to see if there is a path back to UT_ClearDefaultReturnValue. UT_ClearDefaultReturnValue directly calls UT_GetStubEntry and UT_ClearStubEntry, so their implementations (or full callee lists) are required: - UT_GetStubEntry: need its body/callees to verify it does not call UT_ClearDefaultReturnValue (directly) or call other functions that eventually call UT_ClearDefaultReturnValue (indirect recursion). - UT_ClearStubEntry: same reason — inspect its body/callees to ensure no path back to UT_ClearDefaultReturnValue. No type definitions or constants are required for the recursion check; only the function definitions/call graphs of the listed symbols (and any further callees discovered therein) are necessary.
